title: Westchester County Real Estate: January 2026 Market Update
author: Alexandra Reeves
coverImageAlt: Westchester County real estate market data
excerpt: After a strong 2025, Westchester County enters 2026 with record-low inventory, rising prices, and buyers competing fiercely for well-priced homes.
body:
## The Market in One Sentence

Westchester County enters 2026 the same way it left 2025: undersupplied, competitive, and relentlessly expensive.

## Key Metrics — January 2026

Median sale price across Westchester County: **$875,000** — up 5.8% year-over-year. The number of active listings at month's end: **1,842** — down 12% from January 2025 and the lowest January inventory count in seven years.

Homes that were well-priced and well-presented averaged **24 days on market**. Nearly 40% of transactions closed above the original asking price.

## What's Driving the Market

**Inventory remains the story.** New listings are not keeping pace with buyer demand. Many homeowners who locked in 3-4% mortgage rates during 2020-2021 are choosing to stay put rather than trade up into a 7% rate environment. Until rates drop meaningfully, this supply constraint is structural.

**Buyers are competing hard.** For move-in-ready homes in top school districts — Scarsdale, Bronxville, Rye — multiple-offer situations are the norm rather than the exception. I've seen 8-12 offers on well-priced Scarsdale colonials in the first week of listing.

**Luxury is moving.** Properties above $2 million have seen a notable pickup in activity. Remote work flexibility has created a cohort of buyers who can justify the premium for a larger home and yard, knowing they won't commute every day.

## My Outlook for 2026

I expect the first half of 2026 to continue the pattern of 2025: strong demand, limited supply, modest price appreciation in the 4-6% range. If the Fed delivers additional rate cuts and mortgage rates approach 6%, I anticipate a surge of both buyers AND sellers entering the market — which could finally begin to rebalance supply and demand.

For sellers: this is still one of the most favorable environments in a decade. Properly prepared and priced homes are moving quickly.

For buyers: speed and decisiveness matter. Pre-approval should be in hand before you fall in love with a house.
